M.G.L. c. 212 \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212 § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000 and Plaintiff seeks recovery for personal injuries.

M.G.L. c. 223 \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Suffolk Superior Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223 § 1 because the conduct giving rise to this claim occurred in Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 89, \u00a7 2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care to operate and use his vehicle, including its doors, in a reasonably safe manner so as not to endanger other road users, including bicyclists. (See G.L. c. 89, § 2; G.L. c. 90, §§ 14, 17.)

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7\u00a7 14, 17.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care to operate and use his vehicle, including its doors, in a reasonably safe manner so as not to endanger other road users, including bicyclists. (See G.L. c. 89, § 2; G.L. c. 90, §§ 14, 17.)

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant breached his duty of care by negligently opening his vehicle’s door into a marked bike lane without first ensuring it was safe to do so, in violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14, which requires vehicle operators to check for traffic before opening a door.

*See Commonwealth v. Kaplan*, 24 Mass. A.raw_text: *See Commonwealth v. Kaplan*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 726 (1987).
*See Commonwealth v. Kaplan*, 24 Mass. A.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that drivers owe a duty of care to bicyclists, including the duty to exercise reasonable caution before opening vehicle doors.
*See Commonwealth v. Kaplan*, 24 Mass. A.case_name: School Committee of Boston v. Labor Relations Commission
*See Commonwealth v. Kaplan*, 24 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The provided opinion concerns whether Boston school bus drivers are public employees under Massachusetts labor relations law and does not address tort duties of drivers toward bicyclists or the specific duty to exercise caution before opening vehicle doors. There is no discussion of negligence, roadway users, bicyclists, or dooring-related obligations. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about a driver's duty of care to bicyclists.

*See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Stor.raw_text: *See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 360 (1990).
*See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Stor.proposition: The principle of negligence requires compliance with safety-related statutes, the violation of which constitutes evidence of negligence.
*See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Stor.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Stor.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that a violation of a safety-related statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69) does not create negligence per se but is “some evidence” of negligence—precisely the principle described in the proposition. The court emphasizes that common-law negligence elements must still be proven, and that statutory violation alone is not dispositive but is relevant evidence as to negligence regarding the harms the statute was intended to prevent.
*See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Stor.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only 'some evidence' of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968)."

*See Brodeur v. Desrosiers*, 505 F.3d 53.proposition: The Massachusetts “dooring law” codified in G.L. c. 90, § 14 protects bicyclists from harm and imposes a duty on vehicle occupants to ensure safety before opening doors.
*See Brodeur v. Desrosiers*, 505 F.3d 53.support_reasoning: The opinion in Brodeur v. Desrosiers concerns an immigration/asylum claim by an Indonesian national and addresses issues of persecution, standards of review, and credibility in removal proceedings. It does not discuss Massachusetts motor vehicle law, bicyclist safety, or G.L. c. 90, § 14, nor does it mention any “dooring law” or duties of vehicle occupants when opening doors. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the stated proposition about the Massachusetts dooring statute.
*See Brodeur v. Desrosiers*, 505 F.3d 53.relevant_excerpt: We have repeatedly affirmed the BIA’s determinations, made on the evidence submitted in various cases, that there is no ongoing pattern or practice of persecution against ethnic Chinese or Christians in Indonesia. See, e.g., Sipayung v. Gonzales, 491 F.3d 18, 21 (1st Cir.2007); Wijaya v. Gonzales, 201 Fed.Appx. 791, 795 (1st Cir.2006) (per curiam); Teja v. Gonzales, 196 Fed.Appx. 4, 7 (1st Cir.2006) (per curiam); Jaya v. Gonzales, 169 Fed.Appx. 596, 598 (1st Cir.2005) (per curiam).

*See Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.raw_text: *See Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637 (1996).
*See Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.proposition: Courts have also recognized that the foreseeability of harm is central to negligence claims, and conduct that endangers lawful bicyclists is foreseeably harmful.
*See Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*See Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.support_reasoning: The concurrence excerpt acknowledges that foreseeability of harm is relevant to negligence (agreeing that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk created by defendant’s negligence), but it does not discuss bicyclists or conduct endangering lawful bicyclists. It also does not articulate any broader rule that conduct endangering bicyclists is foreseeably harmful. Thus, while it touches on foreseeability generally, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*See Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”
